messages: 99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (16:29): Question about the media API: Seeking works by setting currentTime to a new value (in seconds). Is there a special reason why currentTime isn't readonly and seeking works e.g. with a method seek(), taking a relative value (zero to one), which would cover the case when the duration of the stream isn't known (but it's filesize is) and rough seeking shall still be available.

99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (16:30): (there are media formats without a header containing duration, so all you got is the byte position if the client shouldn't try to find a timestamp at the end of the bytestream)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:31): zero to one relative to the filesize?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:31): (seeming the length isn't known)
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (16:32): yeah, if the duration in "proper time" isn't known one can still seek to an approximate position using the position of the bytestream
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (16:33): this, however, only works if seeking is not taking absolute time. The client can then find a fitting representation
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (16:34): if duration is known: Seek to the position (in seconds or whatever)
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (16:34): if only the length of the bytestream is known: Well, just jump to a position in there
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (16:35): I'm currently trying to implement a subset of the HTML5 media specs for a Java playback applet, which only knows bytepositions and thus always seeks relative
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (16:37): I *could* estimate the total duration in seconds given the current byteposition and the current timestamp the media stream has
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (16:38): but that means the duration will change during playback (and given how dynamic video bitrate is this estimate can be like 1000% off)
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (16:38): (the estimate will first be horrible and be more accurate at the end)

99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (16:39): this isn't just specific to this applet thingie, but for some formats the clients really have to seek to the end of the file and find a timestamp befor the duration is known
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (16:40): it's why doublec has asked for a duration attribute
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (16:40): same solution as for my applet ;-)
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (16:40): not sure it will come though - and whether it's a good solution, because not every author may include that info
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (16:40): most won't
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (16:41): yeah, so the estimate is probably the best you can do
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (16:41): quite frankly I'd hope that currentTime would be currentPosition, which can either be seconds *or* byte position
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (16:41): and a flag indicating what it is
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (16:41): same for duration
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (16:42): but this smells like a hack
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (16:42): or a value marker (e.g. sec,B)

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (17:38): (that's my reading of HTML5, btw, which your inspector now follows perfectly)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:38): I believe that is correct
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:39): Why can we not have headers associating with headers?
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (17:39): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, I think HTML5 will change in this respect (Smart Headers has always allowed header cells to have header cells)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:40): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Hixie doesn't think that it makes sense for some reason I always forget
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:40): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: silly Hixie.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:40): I think he is worried about UI issues (too much information being reported)

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:41): But I think removing that information is premature optimisation and that UAs should be free to compete on which of the associations they read out in different circumstances
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:42): e.g. travelling across a table they might only read the headers that changed, but on a keypress might read everything
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:42): Which I think largely eliminates the problem

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (17:43): in particular, it's needed when there are multiple levels of header cells and the lower levels have repetitve text which is disambiguated by the upper levels. such as: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-archive/2007Aug/att-0003/offset-mess.htm

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (17:44): in HTML5, reading across level 2 of the column headers doesn't report whether you are in the "Quirks Mode" or "Standards Mode" section of the table: http://james.html5.org/tables/table_inspector.py?input_type=type_uri&uri=http%3A%2F%2Flists.w3.org%2FArchives%2FPublic%2Fwww-archive%2F2007Aug%2Fatt-0003%2Foffset-mess.htm&source=&algorithm=html5b
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (17:44): (similarly, level 3 doesn't report whether you are in <body> or <html> for either "Quirks Mode" or "Standards Mode")

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (17:45): in Smart Headers, the headers do associate with each other (so, for example, a user could query the final "scroll" to header "Standards Mode, <html>" which disambiguates where they are): http://james.html5.org/tables/table_inspector.py?input_type=type_uri&uri=http%3A%2F%2Flists.w3.org%2FArchives%2FPublic%2Fwww-archive%2F2007Aug%2Fatt-0003%2Foffset-mess.htm&source=&algorithm=smartheaders
